description: The shoulder muscles, or deltoids, are responsible for various arm movements, including lifting, reaching, and rotating.
The leg muscles, including the quadriceps, hamstrings, glutes, and calves, support the body's weight and facilitate movements like walking, running, and jumping.
The abdominal muscles, or abs, consist of various muscle groups like the rectus abdominis, obliques, and transverse abdominis, which provide core stability and help with trunk movements.
The muscles of the upper legs, such as the quadriceps and hamstrings, are crucial for activities like walking, running, and squatting.
The upper arm muscles, including the biceps and triceps, are involved in various movements like bending and straightening the elbow.
The chest muscles, also known as the pectorals, are a group of muscles that help move the arms and shoulders.
The muscles of the lower arms, such as the wrist flexors and extensors, are involved in activities like gripping and lifting.
Neck muscles provide support and mobility to the head and neck region, allowing for movements like turning and tilting.
Cardiovascular exercises target the heart and lungs, improving overall fitness and endurance.
The core muscles, including the lower back, obliques, and transverse abdominis, provide stability to the spine and pelvis, aiding in posture and movement control.
The chest muscles, also known as the pectorals, are important for movements like pushing and lifting objects.
The shoulder muscles, or deltoids, consist of three heads (front, side, and rear) and are involved in various arm movements, including lifting and rotating the arms.
Lower leg muscles, like the calves, play a vital role in activities such as walking, running, and jumping.
The back muscles, including the latissimus dorsi, traps, and rhomboids, are responsible for stabilizing the spine and facilitating movements like pulling and lifting.
The arm muscles comprise the biceps, triceps, and brachialis, which are responsible for elbow flexion and extension, as well as forearm rotation.
Waist muscles are essential for trunk stability and twisting movements. They include muscles like the obliques and transverse abdominis.
The back muscles, including the latissimus dorsi, traps, and rhomboids, are responsible for stabilizing the spine and facilitating movements like pulling and lifting.
